channel.title: Technology on Gonzalo's thoughts
channel.description: Recent content in Technology on Gonzalo's thoughts

item.title: Product, technology and magic
item.description: New trend My daughters call me a senior and boomer. I’m more a GenX’er, but I pick my battles. They are finishing their first year at uni, so they are in the perfect spot to all the new trends.

item.title: Daily lessons from London trains
item.description: For many people not living in the UK, it will come as a surprise that the railway system in London is quite expensive and provides a really bad service. Train service is not a theme park.

item.title: Google Duplex and robocalls
item.description: You’ve probably seen the video presentation about Google Duplex, the new assistant created by Google that can make phone calls that sound totally human interactions to the human on the other side (and to anyone listening).

item.title: Virtual Reality in macOS (II)
item.description: TLDR; VR on macOS means beta, crashes, unusable WebVR, and no games. But you get to learn a lot. This post explains my experience. It seems this time I’m one of the few non-professionals that has bought an HTC Vive and a Mac after June’s keynote.

item.title: Virtual Reality in macOS (I)
item.description: I have a two year old mid-level Android phone (Moto G 2015) not capable of using Google Cardboard. My tablet is an iPad Mini “1” with iOS9 because it can no longer be upgraded.

item.title: Bubble!!
item.description: In the late 90s there was some craziness in the air. Everybody perceived Internet was going to transform our lives. But we didn’t know how. Companies tried to grow at all costs, setting up what looked like crazy ideas.

item.title: Disruption in Financial Services
item.description: For many people, disruption in Financial Services are new banks that are building the platform from the ground up. Not being tied to legacy systems, make those banks easier to operate.

item.title: Netflix against the user
item.description: I like Netflix. I really do. But there are a few things in their user interface that drive me crazy. You cannot remove a movie from continue watching. You’ve already watched a movie, don’t want to see the credits, but Netflix thinks you haven’t reached the end.

item.title: When the CTO is not management
item.description: Tech startup founded by non-tech founders. Founders know little about technology, so they hire a CTO like they would hire an accountant. CTO is not part of management. Technology gets isolated.

item.title: LetsEncrypt, Paypal and selling fear
item.description: There is a new report that associates Let’s Encrypt with phishing. So lots of people in Twitter started screaming because they read phishing and Paypal in the same sentence. Let’s Encrypt is a foundation that gives certificates away for free.

item.title: Thoughts on the S3 outage
item.description: It’s in the news. Amazon S3, the popular object store crashed yesterday in one of their regions and affected multiple other sites, including Slack and GitHub. So here are some comments about it:

item.title: Fintech: Dinosaurs are doomed
item.description: I’m sick and tired of reading articles describing how the banks are going to buy the new players in Fintech. Yes. It is going to happen. It has already happened. BBVA has already bought Simple and Atom.

item.title: Consumers need to understand…
item.description: Today I was reading this article about excuses from banks for crap services. Then I got to this sentence: Consumers need to understand that the balance you see is not necessarily your actual available balance because there are so many moving partsNo.

item.title: I hate my bank
item.description: Yesterday I was using my bank account, taking money out using a debit card. No way to see the operation since the feed only has old/settled operations. Since the available balance was below what I considered safe, I moved back the money using the same card.

item.title: AWS Summit London 2016
item.description: Today I went to AWSSummit London. It’s a free event dedicated to Amazon Web Services. The event took place at Excel London, excellent venue except for the occasional noise due to planes taking off from the nearby London City Airport.

item.title: Now I remember why I left “security”
item.description: Around the year 2000, I was doing some consulting work for the ISP branch of a Spanish bank. I was creating dynamic web pages (not many people in the IT industry will remember the word CGI)

item.title: Snapchat: I’m getting old
item.description: In the last couple of months I’ve been able to see a growing trend with Snapchat. More and more people I follow in Twitter are testing Snapchat waters. Around a month ago, I installed the app, started registering, think twice…

item.title: AlphaGo, AI, and Philosophy
item.description: I’m fascinated by AlphaGo. I truly am. A week ago I knew nothing about go. Now, I’ve read the rules but I haven’t played a single game. So I’m left to commentators.

item.title: My take on #RIPTwitter
item.description: There is some outrage in Twitter because it has started to implement some changes to its product. There was a change from stars to likes. I think I prefer stars because it conveys a different meaning: when I read something sad, I cannot click in Like, but I would click in star.

item.title: The Netflix of books
item.description: Broken Kindle anyone?A couple of months ago, we were flying back to London after the summer. My 12 year old twin daughters, usually eager video watchers or passionate console players, were avid readers at that moment.

item.title: Evolving or dying
item.description: A friend of mine sent to me a job offer. It caught both her and my attention because it shows a problem very common in Internet companies. The company in question is quite successful in its niche.

item.title: Prepare for FireOS
item.description: I was considering about buying one or two Amazon Fire, when I discovered they’re unlikely to come before Christmas. Granted, the price is amazingly good. 50 quid was already good, so 35 is almost incredible.

item.title: Love your users
item.description: A few years ago, I was leading a small team in charge of developers’ tools and framework. We discovered a bug, and the easiest way to solve it was to make a change in a different piece of functionality that wasn’t technically right, but was being heavily used.

item.title: Banks and users
item.description: A couple of weeks ago, I had an interesting discussion in Twitter about how a Spanish Government body (AEAT, the equivalent of HRMC in the UK or IRS in the US) was offering different “services” in two different websites.

item.title: Think big
item.description: A few weeks ago, I’m not sure why, one of my daughters proposed to create a system to find cars inside garages at the shopping center. The car would locate itself using a GPS and then it would emit via radio.

item.title: Android 4.4.3: Sony Xperia U
item.description: A few months ago, I upgraded the firmware for my Sony Xperia U. It turns out that the place I used to download the firmware updates from, wasn’t providing new updates, so sometime ago, I migrated to a new source of firmware updates.

item.title: Maximizing Macbook Pro's battery
item.description: I have an old Dell Vostro 1720 and an Acer Aspire One AO110. Both are usable (and used), but have no battery. So when I got my shiny brand new Mac, I decided I had to look after the battery.

item.title: Acquisitions
item.description: Today I wanted to talk about two acquisitions. On one side, Facebook and Whatsapp. $19 billion. There are many different opinions. Craziness. Logic. IMO the money paid is crazy, but the deal has a lot of logic for Facebook.

item.title: Techzing wives
item.description: I tend to listen Techzing podcast. It’s a podcast about very different topics, recorded by two geeks, (or developers, and entrepeneurs). I don’t remember when I started listening them. I do remember I started because I wanted to practice English and it was great (Justin is an Englishman and Jason is American).

item.title: Why LinkedIn breach is so important?
item.description: It’s widely spread that there has been a security breach in LinkedIn. At least there is a file with passwords in that social network. Even LinkedIn acknowledges it and suggests it will try to alert users whose passwords have been compromised.

item.title: Google, where are you going?
item.description: I’ve been Google fanboy for a long time. I remember the invitation for Gmail I received around mid-2004. Gmail was a revolution. From 50MB mail space at the time, they offered 1000MB (1GB).

item.title: When companies just don't get it
item.description: I have a two years old Symbian cell phone and a second generation iTouch. I guess that’s enough to explain that until very recently I didn’t pay any attention at all to mobiles apps ads.

item.title: My first mobile application
item.description: I’m learning some technologies. I’m tempted to write new, but they’re not new. I’m learning Ruby on Rails and mobile development. I still have to keep learning Java, and Grails, but I have a project in mind and I wanted to separate clearly from my day to day job, for lots of reasons.

item.title: Some thoughts about Tecnimap 2010
item.description: I’ve been a couple of days in Zaragoza (Spain), participating in Tecnimap 2010 last week. Tecnimap is a conference on IT for the Public Administration in Spain. I had presented a paper about one of the applications I manage: DocelWeb.

item.title: Netbook Operating Systems
item.description: A few months ago I got a new Acer Aspire One A110. It’s an Atom N270 with 512 MB RAM and 8GB SSD hard disk and 8.9’’ screen. It came with a personalized version of a Linux distribution called Linpus Lite based in Fedora 8.

item.title: Yahoo: A declining star (II)
item.description: I wrote on the previous post that for a particular combination of search terms, Yahoo seemed to offer better results than Google. I read long time ago that in fact search was turning to be a commodity.

item.title: Yahoo: A declining star(I)
item.description: I like products coming from Google, and I’m usually less critic with Google’s errors than with others’. I use Google search, Gmail, Blogger… I even have a ridiculous financial position on Google (8 shares).

item.title: Gmail and the future
item.description: As I said on my last post, I think that integration of Video and voice chat could be part of a greater strategy. What would be that strategy? In my opinion it should have two parts.

item.title: 'The day Skype died' revisited
item.description: Sometimes you realize you’ve written a weak post too late. It was my case with yesterday’s annotation. I thought nobody would even read it. But it seems that, because of a trackback at Gmail Blog, I was wrong.

item.title: The day Skype died
item.description: I read it first on Google Operating System, but I haven’t seen too much buzz on the blogs I follow. For me today is the day Skype has definitively died.

item.title: MobuzzTV
item.description: I heard about MobuzzTV for the first time long time ago. I don’t watch news on TV, (I prefer to read than watch), so much less watch on the Internet. I didn’t pay much attention then.
